PASTORAL NOTES
• The Christmas novena begins on 17 December. At this point, the Advent focus shifts to the
Christmas story and the Virgin Mary. These days serve to prepare more directly for the Lord’s
birth (GNLYC 42). This is the best time to hold carols services and to begin to sing Christmas carols in the liturgy.
• During this time, memorials are optional and only the Collect of the memorial may be used at Mass. All other texts are of the day in the Christmas novena.

LI.LBody: Christmas falls next Thursday. It is a holy day of obligation.

After the annual celebration of the Paschal Mystery, the Church has no more ancient custom than celebrating the memorial of the Nativity of the Lord and of his first manifestations, and this takes place in CHRISTMAS TIME.
Christmas Time runs from First Vespers (Evening Prayer I) of the Nativity of the Lord up to and including the Sunday after Epiphany or after 6 January. GNLYC 32-33.
Priests may celebrate or concelebrate three Masses for Christmas day. Bishops and parish priests offer a Mass pro populo on Sundays and holy days of obligation.

For pastoral reasons, the texts of the vigil need not be used at a Wednesday evening Christmas Mass: the midnight texts may be used. The Christmas Mass formularies should be used at the correct time of day: this structure highlights the key theme of night giving way to day, light breaking through the darkness.
Examples of formularies for the Prayer of the Faithful during Christmas Time are given on page 1518 of The Roman Missal.
The Solemn Blessing for the Nativity of the Lord may be used during the Christmas Season (The Roman Missal p 710).

The Nativity of the Lord has its own Octave. This includes feasts that were celebrated in the most ancient liturgical calendars and which have been associated with Christmas through tradition. These feasts include the Holy Family of Jesus Mary and Joseph (the Sunday within the Octave of Christmas, or 30 December on years where there is no Sunday in the Octave), St Stephen (26 December), St John (27 December), Holy Innocents (28 December). The Octave Day of the Nativity of the Lord is the Solemnity of Mary, the Holy Mother of God (1 January).
During the Octave of Christmas, Memorials are celebrated only as “Optional Memorials”. The

Sect.P: Collect of the Saint may be used on this day, but all other texts are those of the Octave of Christmas.

LI.LBody: Texts for the Mass “At the Beginning of the Civil Year” (Roman Missal p 1352) may not be used today. However, these texts may be assimilated into the Prayer of the Faithful on January 1, as petitions are included for peace and for the New Year.
A formula of Solemn Blessing may be found on p 710 of The Roman Missal (The Beginning of the Year) or on p 717 (The Blessed Virgin Mary).
Appropriate petitions may be included in the Prayer of the Faithful for the World Day of Peace.

Tomorrow is the Solemnity of the Epiphany. The Blessing of Homes, traditionally associated with Epiphany, is provided here. The Parish Blessing of Chalk would ideally take place at the end of Masses on Epiphany. The texts for the domestic rite (see p. 27) could be made available to parishioners to take home, along with the blessed chalk.

Sect.H5: THE EPIPHANY BLESSING Marking Homes with Blessed Chalk for the New Year
Sect.P: The ancient custom of marking the door of the home with blessed chalk is a way of incorporating the liturgical feast of the Epiphany as a domestic ritual into the prayer life of the family. Chalk is first blessed in the parish church at Masses for Epiphany and then people are invited to take some home and to mark the lintel of their front door as follows:
The letters C, M and B stand for the traditional names for the Three Wise Men who come seeking Jesus: Caspar, Melchior, and Balthasar. The letters also represent the words
Christus Mansionem Benedicat (May Christ Bless this Abode).

Introduction: On this feast of the Epiphany of the Lord, we rejoice that the light of Christ has come into our world. Today, we invite families to take home a piece of this chalk to mark the front door of your homes as a blessing for the New Year.

Prayer of Blessing: Let us pray. Lord our God, we praise you for the light of creation: the sun, the moon, and the stars of the night. We praise you for the gift of Jesus, your Son, the Light of the World. May your blessing be upon us as we carry this chalk to our homes. May its mark on our doorposts be a sign of your protection and of the presence of the Light of Christ in our homes. In the name of the Father, and the Son, + and the Holy Spirit. Amen.

TR.TD: WORDS TO BE SAID AT HOME

Peace be upon this house and with all of us who live here. Amen. Matthew 2:1-2, 10-11 The wise men from the East came to Jerusalem asking: Where is the child who has been born king of the Jews? For we observed his star at its rising and have come to pay him homage. When they saw that the star had stopped, they were overwhelmed with joy. On entering the house, they saw the child with Mary his mother, and they knelt down and paid him homage. The Gospel of the Lord. Praise to you, Lord Jesus Christ. THE THREE WISE MEN CASPAR MELCHIOR BALTHASAR FOLLOWED THE LIGHT OF THE STAR TO FIND JESUS, THE SON OF GOD, WHO CAME TO LIVE AMONG US TWO THOUSAND AND TWENTY-SIX YEARS AGO. MAY CHRIST BLESS OUR HOME TODAY AND REMAIN WITH US THROUGHOUT THE YEAR. Let us pray. God of mercy, fill our home with the light and love of Christ that it may be a place of hospitality and welcome. May Christ be our shelter when we are at home, our companion when we are away, and our welcome guest when we return. Through Christ our Lord. Amen. Let us bless the Lord. Thanks be to God. In the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit. Amen.

LI.LBody: Lent begins next Wednesday.

Ash Wednesday and Good Friday are days of fast and abstinence. The law of fasting binds those who have completed their eighteenth year, until the beginning of their sixtieth year; the law of abstinence binds those who have completed their fourteenth year (CCL 97, 1251f).

Lent is a penitential season of prayer, self-denial and helping others. In this way, the whole Church prepares for Easter with those who are to be baptised. Other celebrations in Lent (e.g. marriage) must take account of the spirit of penance: musical instruments are only used to sustain singing, and floral decorations are very simple.
Catholics are obliged to receive holy communion at least once a year, in Australia and New Zealand between Ash Wednesday and Trinity Sunday.

LI.LBody: In Lent, the Alleluia is omitted at Mass and at the Hours, even in celebrations of solemnities and feasts.
A homily is recommended on weekdays, especially during the seasons of Advent, Lent and Easter.
From Ash Wednesday, Ordinary Time is interrupted until after Easter Time.

Eucharistic Prayers for Reconciliation I-II are appropriate for use during Lent when there is a theme of reconciliation. They may be used with Prefaces which refer to conversion and penance, such as the Prefaces of Lent.
In Lent, memorials are optional and only the Collect of the memorial is used at Mass. All other texts are of the Lenten day.

Part.P: Mass of the day Intro: Greeting, Opening Prayer only. Homily, Blessing and giving of ashes. Preface of Lent III or IV. Ritual Masses are prohibited.

Praise to you, Lord Jesus Christ, king of endless glory! If today you hear this voice, harden not your hearts. Praise to you, Lord Jesus Christ, king of endless glory! (Cf Ps 94:8)
Mt 6:1-6, 16-18: Your Father, who sees all that is done in secret, will reward you. Blessing and giving of ashes outside Mass is celebrated with the entire Liturgy of the Word.

Sect.P: • The season of Lent is the most appropriate time for celebrating the Sacrament of Penance. Already on Ash Wednesday the people of God has heard the solemn invitation, Turn away from sin and believe the good news. It is fitting to have several penitential celebrations during Lent, so that the faithful may have an opportunity to be reconciled with God and their neighbour and so be able to celebrate the paschal mystery in the Easter Triduum with renewed hearts. RP 13 The Sacrament of Penance is better celebrated before rather than during the Easter Triduum.

LI.LBody: Sample petitions for the Prayer of the Faithful during Lent are provided on pp 1520-1521 of The Roman Missal.

There is an optional Prayer over the People for each day of Lent which may be used at the end of the celebration of Mass. The priest, with hands outstretched over the people, says the prayer, and the people respond, “Amen”. After the prayer, the Priest adds: “And may the blessing of Almighty God, the Father, and the Son, + and the Holy Spirit, come down on you and remain with you for ever.” The people respond, “Amen”.

Sect.P: Eucharistic Prayer II has its own Preface but may be used with other Prefaces, especially those

that summarise the mystery of salvation. Eucharistic Prayer IV has an unchangeable Preface. It may be used when a Mass has no Preface of its own, for example, on weekdays in Lent and Easter and on Sundays in Ordinary Time.

Eucharistic Prayer for Reconciliation I-II may be used when there is a theme of reconciliation. They may be used with other Prefaces which refer to conversion and penance, such as the Prefaces of Lent.

Eucharistic Prayer for Various Needs and Occasions I-IV has its own Prefaces and is intended for use in Masses for Various Needs and Occasions. For the table showing when these Masses are allowed, see pp. 10-11.
Funeral Masses are not allowed on the Sundays of Advent, Lent and Easter, on the Easter
Triduum or holy days of obligation. Ritual Masses are not allowed on these days nor on any Solemnity, Ash Wednesday, Holy Week, the Octave of Easter or All Souls.

Other Masses for the Dead are not allowed on any of these days nor on any Sunday or Feast. Masses for Various Needs and Votive Masses are only allowed on weekdays in Ordinary Time, though if some real need or pastoral advantage requires it, they may be celebrated on weekdays in Advent until 16 December, weekdays in the Christmas and Easter seasons, and on Memorials. (See table, pp. 10-11.)

LI.LBody: The Commemoration of the Lord's Entrance into Jerusalem may take one of three forms:
The procession beginning with the blessing of palms at a second church or another site; it may be held only once at a principal Mass.
The solemn entrance beginning with the blessing of palms in front of the church door or in the vestibule; it may be repeated at well-attended Masses.
The simple entrance of priest and ministers without the blessing of palms, held when there is no procession or solemn entrance.

The Passion may be read in three parts by deacons, priests or lay people; the priest or deacon takes the part of Christ. It is proclaimed without candles, incense, greeting, or signs of the cross. The homily follows.

2 Thursday THURSDAY of HOLY WEEK

Mass Apart from the Chrism Mass and the Evening Mass of the Lord's Supper, all Masses are prohibited. violet Hours Evening Prayer is celebrated only by those unable to take part in the Mass of the Lord's Supper.

LI.LBody: Communion services are prohibited, though communion may be taken to the sick.
The funeral liturgy may only be celebrated outside Mass.

For pastoral reasons, the local Ordinary may permit a second evening Mass or, in the case of genuine necessity, even a morning Mass, but exclusively for those in no way able to take part in the evening Mass.

Sect.P: In the Cathedral
Thursday of Holy Week (morning) or another day towards the end of Lent

white The CHRISM MASS Gloria, Renewal of Commitment to Priestly Service (no Creed, Intercessions). Preface of the Priesthood of Christ and the Ministry of Priests. Rites of Blessing Oils and Consecrating Chrism.
Readings: Is 61:1-3, 6, 8-9: The Lord has anointed me and he has sent me to bring Good
News to the poor, to give them the oil of gladness. Ps 88:21-22, 25, 27: R. For ever I will sing the goodness of the Lord. Rev 1:5-8: Christ has made us a line of kings, priests to serve his God and
Father. Praise to you, Lord Jesus Christ, king of endless glory!

The spirit of the Lord is upon me; he sent me to bring Good News to the poor. Praise to you, Lord Jesus Christ, king of endless glory! (Is 61:1, Lk 4:18) Lk 4:16-21: The spirit of the Lord has been given to me, for he has anointed me.

LI.LBody: The oil of the sick is blessed at the end of the Eucharistic prayer; the oil of catechumens is blessed and the chrism is consecrated after the Prayer after Communion. For pastoral reasons, all three may take place after the Liturgy of the Word.

The Chrism Mass is an important event for the whole diocese for, in it, the local Church shows its care for those being initiated, those designated for the ordained ministry and those who are sick. All are encouraged to take part. To manifest the communion of the priests with their bishop in a leadership of service, the bishop concelebrates with his presbyterium, at least with some priests from different parts of the diocese. This is the context for the renewal of commitment to priestly service which takes place in the words given or in similar words.

There should be only one celebration of the Chrism Mass, given its significance in the life of the diocese, and it should take place in the cathedral or, for pastoral reasons, in another church which has a special significance (Paschale Solemnitatis 36).

Sect.P: • THE SACRED PASCHAL TRIDUUM of the Passion and Resurrection of the Lord shines forth as the high point of the entire liturgical year. The Paschal Triduum begins with the
evening Mass of the Lord’s Supper, has its centre in the Easter Vigil, and closes with Vespers
(Evening Prayer) of the Sunday of the Resurrection. GNLY 18,19

LI.LBody: Unity is expressed by the single celebration of an evening eucharist in which the whole local community gathers to participate. Concelebration is encouraged, even by priests who have taken part in another Mass on Holy Thursday.
The tabernacle is empty before Mass; thus, all at this Mass and on Good Friday receive communion from what is consecrated tonight, a sign of the unity of altar and cross.
Bells may be rung during the Gloria.
The liturgical gesture of washing feet ritualises the Christian ideal of a leadership of service, a service which Christ expresses fully by laying down his life on the cross.
At the beginning of the Liturgy of the Eucharist, gifts for the poor may be presented: this would be a good time for people to make their Project Compassion offering.
The purpose of the solemn reservation of the eucharist as the Mass ends is to provide for communion on Good Friday; adoration until midnight is encouraged but is secondary.
The rite presumes the sacrament is reserved in the eucharist chapel; if the church does not have one, a eucharist chapel is set up for the occasion.
After Mass, the altar is stripped and crosses are removed or covered.

Sect.P: 3 Friday (Fast and abstinence) red FRIDAY of the PASSION of the LORD

All Masses are prohibited. All celebration of the sacraments is strictly prohibited, except for the sacraments of Penance and Anointing of the Sick, though even these are better celebrated before the Triduum towards the end of Lent. Communion is not given outside the Celebration of the Lord's Passion but may be taken to the sick.
Hours of the day

It is recommended that the Office of Readings and Morning Prayer be celebrated publicly in parishes (Tenebrae). Evening Prayer is celebrated only by those unable to take part in the Celebration of the Lord's Passion.

Sect.H5: Celebration of the Passion of the Lord
Sect.P: I. The Liturgy of the Word, readings, homily, solemn intercessions
II. The Adoration of the Holy Cross
III. Holy Communion
Readings: Is 52:13 -53:12: He surrendered himself to death, while bearing the faults of many.

salvation for all who obey him.
Glory and praise to you, Lord Jesus Christ!
Christ became obedient for us even to death, dying on the cross.
Therefore God raised him on high and gave him a name above all other names.
Glory and praise to you, Lord Jesus Christ! (Phil 2:8-9)
Jn 18:1 -19:42: The passion of our Lord Jesus Christ according to John.
(BALLARAT: Anniv. of death of Most Rev. Ronald Mulkearns, 2016)

LI.LBody: The Celebration of the Passion of the Lord takes place about three o'clock or later for pastoral reasons. The altar should be completely bare, without cloths, candles or cross.
The Passion may be read in three parts by deacons, priests or lay people; the priest or deacon takes the part of Christ. It is proclaimed without candles, incense, greeting or signs of the cross.

To make clear the unity of the Easter Triduum, the Celebration of the Passion of the Lord on Good Friday is celebrated by the priest who leads the assembly on Holy Thursday and the Easter Vigil. Where this is not possible, a deacon or lay person may lead the community in parts of the Liturgy of the Hours (i.e. Morning, Evening or Night Prayer), or an appropriate devotion such as the Seven Last Words or the Stations of the Cross.
The ancient tradition of receiving communion on Good Friday links this celebration with the Mass of the Lord's Supper and looks forward to the Eucharist of the Easter Vigil.
After the Celebration of the Passion of the Lord, the Eucharist may be kept privately for the needs of the sick and dying.

Sect.P: All Masses are prohibited. All celebration of the sacraments is strictly prohibited, except for Penance and Anointing of the Sick, though even these are better celebrated before the Triduum towards the end of Lent. Communion may only be given as viaticum.
(violet) Hours of the day
It is recommended that the Office of Readings and Morning Prayer be celebrated publicly in parishes (Tenebrae). Night Prayer is celebrated only by those unable to take part in the Easter Vigil.

white The Easter Vigil in the Holy Night
I. The Solemn Beginning of the Vigil or Lucernarium: Blessing of the Fire, Procession, Exsultet
II. The Liturgy of Word: Readings/psalms/prayers, Gloria, Homily
III. Baptismal Liturgy: Litany, Blessing of water, Baptism, Confirmation, Renewal of baptism

LI.LBody: The Liturgy of Eucharist: Preface of Easter I, (Easter Communicantes, Hanc igitur in Euch. Prayer I)
The Concluding Rites: Dismissal with Alleluia

Let us sing to the Lord; he has covered himself in glory. IV Is 54:5-14: But with everlasting love I have taken pity on you, says the Lord, your redeemer. Ps 29:2, 4-6, 11-13: R. I will praise you, Lord, for you have rescued me. V Is 55:1-11: Come to me and your soul will live. With you I will make an everlasting covenant. Is 12:2-6: R. or if Baptism takes place: Ps 50:12-15, 18, 19: Create a clean heart in me, O God. Rom 6:3-11: Christ, having been raised from the dead, will never die again. Ps 117:1-2, 16-17, 22-23: R. Alleluia! Alleluia! Alleluia! Mt 28:1-10: He has risen from the dead and now he is going before you to
Galilee.

LI.LBody: The entire celebration of the Easter Vigil takes place at night. It should not begin before nightfall and should end before daybreak on Sunday. It is an abuse to begin before it is dark simply so that the Easter Vigil can be scheduled at the customary time of the Sunday Mass on Saturday evening.

The Lucernarium at the bonfire begins the celebration with a joyful proclamation of Christ's resurrection: the readings of the Vigil are heard in the light of the resurrection. If there is no priest or deacon who can sing the Easter Proclamation (Exsultet), it may be sung by a cantor.
The paschal candle is left near the ambo or altar until Pentecost and is alight during liturgical celebrations.

The reading of the word of God is the fundamental element of the Easter Vigil though, where pastoral reasons require it, the number of readings may be reduced. At least three readings from the Old Testament (or in very serious circumstances two) must be retained, including Exodus

L.LI: 14. Silence may replace the responsorial psalms.

LI.LBody: Bells may be rung during the Gloria, but this should not overshadow the more solemn singing of the Alleluia before the gospel.

Help with integrating the rites of baptism, confirmation and reception into full communion into the Easter Vigil is available in Rite of Christian Initiation of Adults (see especially appendix 1). The renewal of baptismal promises is our annual opportunity as adults to reaffirm the faith and commitment of our baptism.

The Liturgy of the Eucharist is the climax of the Vigil. Receiving the body and blood of the Lord from the altar is the ultimate sign of our belonging to the Church and of our participation in the death and resurrection of Christ.
The dismissal with the double Alleluia continues for the Easter octave.

Sect.P: 5 SUNDAY Solemnity with octave white SUNDAY of the RESURRECTION

Mass during the day, Gloria Easter Sequence is sung, Creed or Renewal of baptismal promises. Preface of Easter I, (Easter Communicantes, Hanc igitur in Euch. Prayer I) Dismissal with Alleluia Ritual Masses and funeral Masses are prohibited.

Hours of Easter Sunday The Easter Vigil takes the place of the Office of Readings (Te Deum).

LI.LBody: The sprinkling with water from the Easter Vigil would be an appropriate introductory rite unless this takes place with the renewal of baptismal promises. The introductory rites should not be penitential in tone.
If there are infants to be baptised, it may be particularly apt to do so during an Easter Sunday Mass.
The Sacred Paschal Triduum ends with Evening Prayer – the Easter Season has already begun.
The celebration of the octave of Easter is most important: these days rank more highly than solemnities (see p. 8).
EASTER TIME: The fifty days from the Sunday of the Resurrection to Pentecost Sunday are

Sect.P: celebrated in joy and exultation as one feast day, indeed as one ‘great Sunday’. These are the
days above all others in which the Alleluia is sung. The Sundays of this time of year are considered to be Sundays of Easter… GNLYC 22-24

Evening Prayer of Pentecost (PALMERSTON NTH: Patronal Feast)

LI.LBody: Pentecost Sunday is the last day of the Easter Season. The Easter Season concludes after Evening Prayer II.
The Easter candle is lit at all Masses for Pentecost. Following Evening Prayer II, it is given a place of honour in the baptistery.
The proper Sequence, which is included before the Gospel Acclamation, should be sung.
The dismissal with the double Alleluia is used.

For pastoral reasons, the texts of the Pentecost Vigil need not be used at a Saturday evening Mass to celebrate the feast. However encouragement should be given to the prolonged celebration of Mass in the form of a Vigil, whose character is not baptismal as in the Easter Vigil, but is one of urgent prayer after the example of the Apostles and disciples who persevered together in prayer with Mary the Mother of Jesus as they awaited the Holy Spirit. (Easter Feasts, no. 107)

Sect.P: On weekdays in Ordinary Time, the priest may choose the Mass texts from:
-the previous Sunday in Ordinary Time or any other Sunday in Ordinary Time,
-an optional memorial of any saint inscribed in the martyrology for that day with texts from a
suitable common,
-a Mass for Various Needs and Occasions, a Votive Mass or a Mass for the Dead.
In arranging the celebration, the Priest should be attentive rather to the common spiritual good
of the People of God than to his own inclinations. GIRM 355c, 352 ORDINARY TIME Eighth week For Pastoral Notes for Ordinary Time, see p. 89.

Sect.P: 28 SUNDAY
PASTORAL NOTES FOR ORDINARY TIME

LI.LBody: Mass ad libitum: On weekdays in Ordinary Time, the priest may choose the Mass texts from:
the previous Sunday in Ordinary Time or any other Sunday in Ordinary Time,
an optional memorial of any saint inscribed in the martyrology for that day with texts from a suitable common,

L.LI: o a Mass for Various Needs and Occasions, a Votive Mass or a Mass for the Dead. In arranging the celebration, the Priest should be attentive rather to the common spiritual good of the People of God than to his own inclinations. GIRM 355c, 352

LI.LBody: Special Intentions at Sunday Mass.

Sect.P: The Sunday liturgy cannot be divorced from daily life and the realities of our world. The joys and hopes, the grief and anguish of the people of our time, especially of those who are poor or afflicted, are the joys and hopes, the grief and anguish of the followers of Christ as well.

Vatican II GS 1 The needs of the world and the local parish can be mentioned in the homily and intercessions, but special intentions – for example, Fathers’ Day – cannot take over the Sunday liturgy for it is always the Paschal Mystery of Jesus’ death and resurrection which we celebrate at Mass.

LI.LBody: The Masses and Prayers for Various Needs and Occasions and Votive Masses contain four Prefaces not found elsewhere in the Roman Missal: Preface for the Unity of Christians (p. 1337); Preface I and II of the Holy Spirit (pp. 1405 and 1408); Preface of Mary, Model and Mother of the Church (p. 1412). (See Index of Prefaces, pp. 1552-1556)

Eucharistic Prayer II has its own Preface but may be used with other Prefaces, especially those that summarise the mystery of salvation. Eucharistic Prayer IV has an unchangeable Preface. It may be used when a Mass has no Preface of its own, for example, on weekdays in Lent and Easter and on Sundays in Ordinary Time. Eucharistic Prayer for Reconciliation I-II may be used when there is a theme of reconciliation. They may be used with other Prefaces which refer to conversion and penance, such as the Prefaces of Lent. Eucharistic Prayer for Various Needs and Occasions I-IV has its own Prefaces and is intended for use in Masses for Various Needs and Occasions. For the table showing when these Masses are allowed, see pp. 10-11 of the Ordo. Eucharistic Prayers for use in Masses for Various Needs together with the Eucharistic Prayers for Reconciliation are found in an Appendix to the Order of Mass on pp. 787-830 of the Roman Missal.
Solemn Blessings: There are six Solemn Blessings provided in the Roman Missal for optional use during Ordinary Time (nos. 9-14, pp. 714-717).

LI.LBody: A priest may celebrate or concelebrate Mass three times on All Souls’ Day, as long as the celebrations occur at different times of the day (GIRM 204). Normally, a priest may not celebrate more than once a day, though the bishop may for a good reason allow priests to celebrate twice in a day or even, if pastoral need requires it, three times on Sundays or holy days of obligation (CCL 905)

If a priest celebrates more than one Mass during All Souls Day, the second is to be offered for the souls of all the faithful departed and the third for the intentions of the pope. No offering may be received for either of these Masses.
November is a special time to pray for the dead. A plenary indulgence may be gained for the

Sect.P: dead, once only, by visiting a church on 2 November and praying the Lord’s Prayer and the
Creed. Three conditions are required for gaining the indulgence: sacramental confession, eucharistic communion, and prayer for the pope’s intentions. (Norms 15.7)

LI.LBody: Christmas falls on Friday of next week– it is a holy day of obligation.

The Christmas novena begins on 17 December. At this point, the Advent focus shifts to the Christmas story and the Virgin Mary. These days serve to prepare more directly for the Lord’s birth (GNLYC 42). This is the best time to hold carols services and to begin to sing Christmas carols in the liturgy. During this time, memorials are optional and only the Collect of the memorial may be used at Mass. All other texts are of the day in the Christmas novena.

LI.LBody: Christmas Day is a holy day of obligation.

After the annual celebration of the Paschal Mystery, the Church has no more ancient custom than celebrating the memorial of the Nativity of the Lord and of his first manifestations, and this takes place in CHRISTMAS TIME.
Christmas Time runs from First Vespers (Evening Prayer I) of the Nativity of the Lord up to and including the Sunday after Epiphany or after 6 January. GNLYC 32-33.
Priests may celebrate or concelebrate three Masses for Christmas day. Bishops and parish priests offer a Mass pro populo on Sundays and holy days of obligation.

For pastoral reasons, the texts of the vigil need not be used at a Thursday evening Christmas Mass: the midnight texts may be used. The Christmas Mass formularies should be used at the correct time of day: this structure highlights the key theme of night giving way to day, light breaking through the darkness.
The Solemn Blessing for the Nativity of the Lord may be used during the Christmas Season (The Roman Missal p 710).
Examples of formularies for the Prayer of the Faithful during Christmas Time are given on page 1518 of The Roman Missal.

The Nativity of the Lord has its own Octave. This includes feasts that were celebrated in the most ancient liturgical calendars and which have been associated with Christmas through tradition. These feasts include the Holy Family of Jesus Mary and Joseph (the Sunday within the Octave of Christmas, or 30 December on years where there is no Sunday in the Octave), St Stephen (26 December), St John (27 December), Holy Innocents (28 December). The Octave Day of the Nativity of the Lord is the Solemnity of Mary, the Holy Mother of God (1 January).
During the Octave of Christmas, Memorials are celebrated only as “Optional Memorials”. The

Sect.P: Collect of the Saint may be used on this day, but all other texts are those of the Octave of Christmas.
